Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After having completed for you, O my son, this book, which is the last of the knowledge in medicine with its complement, and having reached the end of it through its expositions and his declarations, I wished to complete it for you with this Treatise, which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	For operation with the hand has been laid low in our region and in our time, and the knowledge of it has perhaps entirely perished, and its trace has entirely disappeared, and there remained from it only small descriptions in ancient books, which were changed by hand: and they incurred error and hesitation until its intentions were closed off and its vision was lengthened. It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise in it according to the way of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation: and that I should come with the forms of Cauterii's tools, and the other tools of operation: since it is made from its declaration addition, and from its operation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good artisan of it with his own hand is not found in our time is this: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to be exercised before that in the science of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the joints of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and have knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and sinews, and their number, and their egressions, and the pulses of the veins, and the quieting of them, and the exits of the places of them.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And on account of this Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work is few, and especially in the art of hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	Indeed, we have already spoken of that at the entrance of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since those who are not aware of what we have said about anatomy are not spared from falling into the error in which men perish: just as I have seen many of those who are formed from this science and boast about it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That is because I have seen a stupid doctor cut open a scrophulous abscess on the neck of a woman and cut some arteries in her neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed, until she died in her hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another doctor who presumed to remove a stone from a man who had grown old, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he reached him and removed it with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I had already been called to remove it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the weakness of the man that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another doctor who received a bribe from a certain duke of our land for medicine: and it happened to the black eunuch who was with him, a fracture near the calcaneum in his leg: and the doctor hurried with his ignorance, and tied the fracture over the wound with bandages, and with strong bandaging, and did not let the wound breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he healed him according to his own desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he sent him away for several days, and told him not to untie the bandage: and it stood thus until his leg became an abscess, and his foot, and he came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	Therefore I was called to him: and I hurried to untie the bandage: and following this, there was peace, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, corruption was already confirmed in the member, and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, corruption ceased to wander in the member until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced the carbuncular tumor, and it became ulcerated after days, until its evil was revealed to its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, because when cancer is pure from melancholic humor, then it is not necessary to approach it with iron at all, unless there is a member that can tolerate it, so that the whole of it is cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And because of that, my son, it is necessary for you to know that the operation with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation with which safety is associated, and the operation with which there is danger in many positions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already awakened in every place of this book, in which operation comes, in which there is fear and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to beware of that and abandon it, so that the fool does not find a way to speak and disgrace.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take the measure with solicitude and protection, and your infirm ones with facility and firmness, and use the better way leading to salvation and praiseworthy succession through the grace of God: and leave terrible difficulties of healing: and remove your souls from that which makes you fear, so that doubt may enter upon you in your faith and your benefit.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is rather remaining to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galenus already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not heal bad difficulties: so that you are not called bad doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now however, this Treatise has been divided into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of the Cautery with Fire, and the Cautery with Sharp Medicine, arranged from beginning to end, including the forms of instruments and tools for cauterization, and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Of Cutting and Perforation, Bloodletting and Phlebotomy, and Wounds: and Extraction of Arrows, and similar things: and the entire Chapter arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Of Restoration, and Dislocation, and Cure of Twisting, and similar things: arranged from beginning to end, including the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Of the Jaw, and the Harm of Cauterization: and with which constitutions it is suitable, and at what time: and if with iron, or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	However, before I remind you of the operation with it, it is necessary that I say about the quality of its Jaw, and the harm of that: and in which constitution it appears.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the speech about the quality of the Jaw of the Cautery, and its harm, is a long and subtle speech, a knowledge, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Also many wise men spoke about it, and they disagreed in it: and to me indeed it is insufficient by the words of them, fearing the lengthening.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the Cautery brings universally to every constitution, which is with matter, and without matter: excepting two constitutions, which are the constitution hot without matter, and the constitution dry without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In a warm and dry compound with matter, they separated.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that the cauterizing iron of the juvenile was in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of that, namely that the cauterizing iron is not suitable for the illness which is from warmth and dryness: because the nature of fire is warmth: and unsuitable is it, that one should be healed from the illness of warmth and dryness with warmth and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the opposite of that said: that by cauterizing, a cure is made for every illness of warmth and dryness which happens in the bodies of men: because when you compare the body of man, and its moistures, to the compound of fire, you find the body of man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say by his word: because from experiment he has shown me that many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However it is not necessary to come to that, unless he who has already been tested, and exercised in the chapter of cauterization exercise last, and knows the diversity of human compounds, and the disposition of illnesses in themselves, and their causes, and the accidents of them, and the time of them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	And from other compounds there is not upon you fear: and especially in illnesses which are cold and moist.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For now all physicians have gathered upon them: and they did not separate in cure with cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know you children, that from the secret of cure with cauterization with fire, and its goodness above cauterization with burning medicine is: because fire is simple, whose action does not reach, except to the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm another member joined with it, unless a little harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of medicine reaches as far as to extend from the body: and perhaps it causes difficulty in healing a member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	However, fire, due to its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do that unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed, we have now become aware of that through experiment, because of the length of service and study with the art, and position above truth of things: and for that reason I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not, because it is not allowed for this my book, I would bring to you a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies of its expulsion, which expels sufferings demonstrated by philosophical speech, which would be remembered by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my sons, that they themselves disagree in the time when it is fitting to do cauterization, and they set a better time for the truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say, that cauterization is fitting at every time: because the accidental harm is sunk in the benefit, which is drawn with the cauterizer.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Especially if cauterization is for pain from necessary pains, strong, urgent ones who do not tolerate delay: because it is feared that something evil may happen which is greater than the small harm that happens through delay.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And may not fall into your minds, my sons, that which they do not fear, namely that the common people and stupid physicians, namely that to the pain which is healed by cauterization, there is not always return: and they put this consequence, and the matter is not as they think: because cauterization is not, except in place of medicine, which changes the complexion, and dries moistures which are cause why pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, the excessive use of cauterizing can be detrimental to the medicine due to its speed of healing, its effectiveness, and its strong influence over the body. It is possible for the sickness to return at a later time according to the nature of the infirm person, the location of their sickness, and its strength. Also, it can be caused by the accumulation of excessive substances within their body, or from foods and similar causes that led to the application of the cauterization unless the sickness returns.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle sickness in a member with few excessive substances and moisture, such as a tooth cauterization due to pain and similar causes, is possible that this pain does not return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the common saying that cauterization is the last of the medicines is correct, not as they intend in it: because they believe that there is no cure that corresponds with the medicine, nor with another after the fall of the cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The matter is indeed the opposite of that, and their intention, that cauterization is the last of the medicines, is not so, unless when we administer modes of cure in some sicknesses, and those medicines do not correspond: then we administer at the end of the matter cauterization, and it corresponds: then it falls, that cauterization is the last of the medical arts, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients indeed said that cauterization with gold is better than cauterization with iron: and they did not say this unless because of the equality of gold, and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that it does not make pus in the place of cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	However, it is not absolutely true that I have already proven and discovered that it does not work in certain bodies without other things.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And a cautery with it is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you put the cautery into the fire from gold, it is not indicated to you when it is burned according to the amount that you want, because of the redness of gold: and when it approaches the heat, and if you add more to it, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls from that into the occupation: and for that reason, the cautery with iron is made by us faster and closer, from straightness to the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And indeed, I have already arranged this Chapter on Cautery, according to chapters: and I have arranged them from head to foot, so that those seeking it may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the head at the collarbone.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is applied to the dominion of moisture and cold over the brain: which two are causes of sweat, and multitude of discharges of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and multitude of sleep, and pain of the teeth, and pain of the throat: and universally all kinds of distress, which occur from cold, such as paralysis, and sweats, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar diseases to those distresses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is, that you order the sick person: to be emptied at first with a cleansing solution, head three nights, or four, according to what requires the power of the sick person, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your thumb on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever your middle finger reaches that spot, mark the location with a pen.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the cauterizing iron of olive oil: its form is as follows.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with the pen, with a downward movement, as your hand is gradually tightened, and you turn it back.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly withdraw your hand, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the amount of bone from the skull is equal to the amount of alkali or zeuberg, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the same iron, or with another if it is cooled: until you see the bones that I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink the solution with the wound, and place it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the salt water drunk on the wound on butter, and leave it on the spot until the scab of the fire is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with the ointment tetrapharmacon until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	Now they have said that the more the wound remains open, the more pus is emitted: therefore it is better and more healing.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized until the bone: and the cauterizing iron should be held until something of the density of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is scraped after what was burned from the bone, then it is cared for.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Some say that when the cauterizer reaches the last part, it should be pressed against the bone until an impression is made in the form of a crescent: or with an instrument like that which women place between their teeth for the purpose of learning the alphabet: and they believe that vapors from the head will escape through this place, and the wound will remain open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be dressed until it heals.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	To me, however, these two kinds of cauterizer do not appear at all except in certain men according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And it is better to leave it alone with its own health, in my opinion.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head becomes weakened from the solution of its natural continuity, just as we have shown in other members: and especially when the head of an invalid is weak by nature: and indeed the first kind of cauterizer is more saving and better for me, and I use it: therefore, work with it in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is chronic pain in the whole head, and it is prolonged in the invalid, and he uses hemlock, and coals, and head-cleansers, and oils, and plasters:
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	Especially if he has already been cauterized with the one cauterizer which we have mentioned, and does not apply anything from them: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the invalid is strong by nature, and is not weak, and has found a violent cold: then cauterize with another cauterizer under it slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it on top of all the horns of its own head with the cauterizer, so that the skin does not pass through, and a quantity of bone is exposed, as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with a single cauterizing iron at the back of its head, in the place called the "uas": and it is the location where the windpipe is placed: and raise your mat (or blanket) in this, and do not uncover its mouth.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For indeed it has found a remedy for that very severe pain, and different from the pain of all other cauterizations of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this cauterizing iron in its place: and it must be a cauterizing iron by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of its head more subtly with the cauterizing iron by which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	ON THE METHOD OF CAUTERIZING IN HEMICRANIA, BOTH WITH A BURNING MEDICINE AND WITH AN IRON.
Caput IIII.	HEAD IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	WHEN PAIN AND SORENESS OCCUR IN A PART OF THE HEAD, AND THE PAIN EXTENDS UP TO THE EYE, AND IS CLEANSED WITH REMEDIES FOR CLEANSING THE HEAD, AND THE REST OF THE CURE IS ADMINISTERED, AS I SAID IN THE DIVISIONS OF ILLNESSES, AND IT DOES NOT HEAL ALL OF IT: THEN CAUTERIZATION IS DONE IN TWO WAYS: EITHER CAUTERIZATION WITH A SHARP MEDICINE BURNING, OR WITH AN IRON.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	BUT THE CAUTERIZING IRON WITH A SHARP MEDICINE BURNING IS, THAT YOU TAKE ONE Tooth of garlic, AND REMOVE ITS SHELL, AND CUT OFF ITS EXTREMITIES FROM BOTH SIDES.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	THEN CUT THE PLACE OF THE PAIN AT THE TIME WHEN THE BROAD LANCET IS USED, UNTIL THERE IS A LOCUS UNDER THE SKIN, IN WHICH THE TOOTH IS CAPTURED.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	THEN INSERT IT INTO ITS SKIN, UNTIL IT IS HIDDEN: THEN STRAP OVER IT WITH A PIECE OF CLOTH IN DECENT CONSTRICTION, AND LET IT GO FOR FIFTEEN HOURS, THEN DISSOLVE IT, AND EXTRACT THE GARLIC, AND LET HIM REST FOR TWO DAYS, OR THREE: AFTER THAT, PUT ON IT BANDAGE SOAKED IN BUTTER, UNTIL THE PLACE BECOMES PUS: THEN CARE FOR IT WITH OINTMENT UNTIL IT HEALS.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines, which I have written about in my twelfth treatise on Burning Medicaments.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	However, the cauterization of that with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The cauterization with fire, which has this form.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called the Clavil, because its form is like the form of a claw, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it is a small elevation.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand: and you will turn the iron gradually with speed: and the quantity that is burned from the thickness of the skin, is like its middle.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand, so that the artery, which is below, does not burn and there is no loss of blood flow.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then take the wound and soak it in salt water, and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days: then place the wound with butter: afterwards care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this hemicrania with the second edge of the small cauterizer.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And avoid the incision of the artery in this hemicrania, not the ancient one properly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in the ancient hemicrania.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating the hemicrania, with what we said about the previous cure, and what we said in the divisions of ailments, and it does not benefit from the cure: and you see from the ailment, that what we said about the first cauterization with medicine, or with the cauterizer with fire, does not suffice for it, then it is necessary to burn the small cauterizer, until it becomes white after the sign of pain with a line, whose length is the middle of a finger, or something like that: and place your hand halfway, and hold it until you cut the artery, and go through to the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to guard against the continuation of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, so as not to be burned by the side or the nerve that moves it, from which a spasm may occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And let this be over the guard and the precaution against the flow of blood from the severed artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its severing there is fear, and especially for him who does not know what it does, and is not studious or experienced: and he leaves the operation with it first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with the remembrance of the management of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own manner and in its own place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the pain that this cauterizer does not suffice for him, and you see the weak body bearing the cauterizer in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, take care of the wound until he is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cauterizer which we said in the chapter of extracting the artery with a cauterizer having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more fitting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing in ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold, and it is cured with solutions, and the rest of the cure as we said in division, and the pain is not removed, then cauterize with fire: and this is what is called a prick, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then pricks with it after its ignition around the ear entirely, as it is turned: or around both, if the pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And withdraw yourself with the cauterizer a little from the root of the ear after you have marked the places with the cauterizer: and let the quantity of the cauterizer be ten pricks in every ear, and about that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the affected areas until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the method of cauterizing in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture that is cured with cauterization is only from the types that occur from phlegm, as we said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And the absence of cauterization of the type that occurs from dryness and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of torture with honey, and capitpurges, and gargarisms, and your cure does not help, then it is necessary for you to cauterize the sick person with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and second a little lower from his time, and third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterization on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Because softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is to cauterize the sick person with the cauterization directly at the tip of the upper ear under the horn of the head a little: and another in the time: whose length is according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cauterization until the quantity of half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterization, and it is a species from a knife, whose form was mentioned before: but it is not too sharp, as you see: and it is necessary that the knife be a little too thick.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the affected areas with what preceded until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing in old apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy is old, and you treat it with what we said, and your medication does not help, and the sick person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizations on all the horn of his head, and with the cauterization in the middle of his head, as we said, and with the cauterization in the back of his head, according to what preceded: and the method of cauterization should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Even cauterization is performed with a cautery on the mouth of the stomach: and it is more final.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is treated, with what preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterization in Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the drink first give great hiera powder, and purifying pills cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the sick person all over, and place on his occiput the plaster of synapi described in the treatise on plasters: and place it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is indeed the method of cauterization: and do it according to order, as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then perform three cauterizations on the posterior part of his head, which are descending from the superior part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and place between every cauterization the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization, with what preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish an addition, and the sick person is tolerating this: then perform cauterization on the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish an addition: then cauterize him over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him, until he is healed: and let the cauterization be oily according to the form which was previously given.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterization in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed in the cleansing of the head with hiera, and with what we said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize him in the middle of his head, and with a cauterization on every horn of his head, and on the back of his neck, and three on the spines of his neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If you lack the ability to tolerate many of these softening methods for the body and are weak, and the pain is strong: then cauterize it with four cauteries on the spines of the back, and the last one with a cauterizer until it burns the most of its skin, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it heals: and thus cauterize with oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic should not be cauterized unless he is the one whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore it is necessary to cleanse his brain first with vinegar, and with the rest of the cure which we mentioned in division: when he is weak, or is not able to bear the taking of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if it is a child who does not bear medicines, then the gargle is administered, and cleansing mastications of the brain are given before many days with good nutrition.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, and then cauterize him with a cauterizer in the middle of his head, according to what preceded in method: and with another cauterizer in the back of his head, and on every horn of his own head with a cauterizer.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if he is weak and strong, and is able to bear it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I said in having paralysis, and softening of the body on the spines of the neck, and the spines of the back: and the cauterizer should be oily according to the method which preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if he is weak, then place the thin cauterizer in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize with the cauteries we mentioned in one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of humors flowing down to melancholy, and there is a weak moist body, then give him a drink that cleanses his brain, according to what preceded in division: then shave the sick head, and make afterwards a well-made tortellini from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the sick one sitting squarely held from every part.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more fitting from old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it gently over a fire with measured heat, which the finger could bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let him go until he is cooled.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the sick one once a week, with good management of his other affairs, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small points as much as possible, except that you hold the hand with the cauterizer: indeed it should be smelling.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cauterization humidifies the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place on it a wet cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing in water flowing down to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water is declared to you in the eye by signs which I said in division, then begin and give the sick one a drink with it that cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard him from all moistures, and make him sit in the bath, on fasting days for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct him to cut off his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over the two temples with two cauteries, if there is an onset of water in both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is an onset of water in one eye: and cut off all the veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauterization be long in the width of the temples: and beware of blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with any possible medicine: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and caution against blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, under two bones, with two last cauterizations produced.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in the eyes of olden times.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are olden, persistent: and they are on the veins, and arteries that are in the manifest exterior of the head, it is verified that that is from superfluities cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same cauterization that I told in the onset of water descending, cauterization in the middle of the head, and two cauterizations over the two temples, and two cauterizations in the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need additional, then cauterize it on every side of the eye carefully, over the extreme of the eyebrow with a small cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in the nostril discharge.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it, with that which we said in the division, and there is no remedy: then hasten, and give in the weak medicine for three nights: then cut off his head, and cauterize it in the middle with a fat cauterization.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then, cauterize the eyelid with a cautery hook, applying two cauteries, one above each eyebrow, just beneath the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the cautery hook.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing for relaxation of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is relaxed from pain or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with a single cautery and this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above each eyebrow a little with two cauteries in every part: and they should be extended from both temples: and the length of all the cauteries should be according to the length of the eyebrows: and do not let your hand touch the cautery, but according to the quantity that burns the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cauterizing the eyelid when hairs point towards the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery in this case is according to two methods: either a cautery with fire: or a cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cautery with fire, however, instruct the sick person before it, so that he may let go of his hairs, if it is from those who remove them, until they are extended and evened out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if they point at his birth: then close his eyes with a bandage, so that they may not move, until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and evened out, then place the head of the sick person in your lap: then mark on the eyelid with a hot iron, a sign that it is according to the figure of myrtle leaves: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a moistened cotton pad on the albumen or on the mucilage of psyllium over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply a cauterizing iron with this shape.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the shape you indicated gradually in several strokes, until the surface of the skin is burned, which appears like the figure of a myrtle leaf, entirely.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your work's health is that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted and the hairs raised at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So wash your hand then, and let it rest for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place a cotton pad with butter on it over it until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If some of the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cauterizing iron on that spot, as you did first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hairs are on the lower part, then cauterize that spot until it returns to its natural place: and so it will not prick the eye with the hairs.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ On the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	You should order the sick person to let go of the hairs until they grow and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make a shape of a myrtle leaf from paper and cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from the known soap and from the unsoaked chalk of each ounce I or about that: then rub them together with good friction, and make it with speed, so that it does not freeze.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take a piece from that on the cloth you made like the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a moistened cotton pad in an egg white: and let the head of the sick person be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, since its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore he persisted in what he found to be the bite, then let go of the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the bite is quieted, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid raised, as it is raised with contraction with fire, or with incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat on it from the medicine on the place where it does not imprint the medicine, and does not stain, until your operation equals, and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place on it a cotton pad with butter, until the burn of the skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with diaphenhydramine ointment, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you at the operation, that you guard the last guard, lest something fall into the eye from the medicine.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after days, and something fighting from the hair is in the eye, then repeat the medicine on that place which softens from the eyelid properly, as you did first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of the leaf of myrtle.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of men vary in size and symmetry.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore according to that be your consideration: and do not hide the path of righteousness to him who has a desire for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating a fistula, since as we mentioned in the divisions of diseases, and your cure does not succeed: then, it is necessary for you to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head between his hands thus, so that he does not move, nor act with his own head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a cotton swab soaked in a solution of oui, or in a mucilage of psyllium on his eye: then heat the cauterizing iron, whose form is thus.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the form of the pen feather of a quill from one end, with which the cauterizing iron is made: and if you wish it to be piercing up to the other end, and if you wish it to be upwards, then test thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this concave is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it: and if it is not open, then open it, and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place then on it the cauterizing iron, which is made fiery.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold with it your hand for a moment near the cauterizing iron from the eye, to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not err, or disturb the sick person: and place the cauterizing iron in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you reach the beginning of your cauterizing iron up to the bone, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cauterizing iron once, or twice, if you need it: and let it go for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a poultice with butter on it, and care for it with a drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If it has passed forty days and is not healed: then place a sharp, corrosive medicine on it until the bone is removed: and cut it according to how it comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some of the first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Bend to the place of the fistula, and plug it: then place in the wound a thin cannula, that is, a thin needle, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour in a quantity of drachma from the melted lead, and hold your hand with the cannula well retained, and do not move it at all weakly, so that it does not run, or the melted lead reaches his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place on the weak person's eye a poultice soaked in white of egg, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a marvelous cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with what we said from cauterization, and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer the opening of the nose, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to how it comes to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterizing in wounds of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Frequently wounds occur in the lip, which are called "pili," and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you care for these wounds, with what we said in the division of diseases, and not a cure is combined, then a small cauterizing iron, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the sharpness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it quickly on those incisions, until the cautery reaches the depth of the incisions.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the caustic, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ On the method of cauterizing a mouth ulcer.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus, and bursts: afterwards it becomes putrid, and pus runs out, and a fistula forms: then care for it, and the cure does not improve in it, then it is necessary to use a burning cautery according to the amount that fits into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert it into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the burning iron reaches the depth and end of it: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it after that, with what we said about the cure until it heals.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is cut off and healed, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place, and remove the bone of the corrupt part according to what comes into its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing gums, and molten teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is molten due to moisture, and the teeth are moved, and you care for it with medicines, and it does not improve: then place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then a burning iron, of which the shape will come after these, so that you place a cannula on the tooth: and insert the burning iron into it quickly: and hold your hand for a little while, until the sick person feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And retract your hand: then repeat the cauterization several times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the sick person will fill their mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour: and then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened by motion, and the jaw becomes soft and contracts, and thus the corrupted moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Chapter on the method of cauterizing in tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to coldness, or there is fever in it, or worms, and no cure is found with medicines: then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterization with butter: or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But cauterization with butter is, so you take calf's butter, and boil it in an iron spoon, or in a vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a cloth, and cover it over the end of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then submerge it in the boiled butter: and place it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools: then repeat it several times, until the power of fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, submerge a cloth, or a rag in cold butter, and place it on the painful tooth: and place a hot iron on it, until fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cauterization with fire is, so you direct it to a tube of air, or an iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there should be something thick in its body, so that the sharpness of fire does not reach the mouth of the sick person.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then cauterize with fire, whose form will come: and place it on the tooth: and hold your hand until the cauterization cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Perform this procedure several times, as the pain will be alleviated either on that same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary for the sick person to fill his mouth with good charcoal and hold it for one hour, then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the shape of the cauterizing iron.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with any tip of the needle according to what is possible; and this is the shape of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing in Strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When Strophuli are caused by phlegm, and by cold humors, and they do not obey the digestive process through medicines, and you want to quickly promote their digestion: then use a flat cauterizing iron, whose shape is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that smoke comes out from the cauterizing iron through the other end: and place it on the abscess once, and twice if you need to, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then place the cauterizing iron according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it go for three days, and place on it a compress soaked in an infusion, until the burn caused by the fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with tooth ointment, until the shape of the cannula is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing in a hoarse voice, and in constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moisture is accumulated on the bronchial tube, and especially when it is with a cold temperament, then it is necessary for the sick person to be evacuated first with dissolved medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize the wound itself at the root of the neck in a hollow place: and be careful not to let the cauterizer touch the throat, nor on the skin, unless something of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize the wound itself with another cauterizer at the junction of the neck in the last spinal process of it: and let the cauterizer be narrow according to the mode that preceded.
