When therefore it happens to someone that thing, then hasten with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place on top of it your finger: and press it much, until the blood is blocked under your finger, and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place on the small cautery of wax and many more: and blow on them until they are burned greatly.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or a few, or many, according to the wound and the place in which the artery is broken, and place the cautery on the vein, after which you remove your finger quickly: and hold the cautery until the blood is cut.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If the thorn is expelled from the wound and the finger is cut off from the opening of the artery, and the heated iron is extinguished, then take another heated iron quickly, from the irons that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not cease to do this with one after another, until the blood stops flowing.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, lest you burn the nerves which are there, and another evil may occur on the weak part.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is impossible to remove it: especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with an iron, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with the extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the ends of it are contracted, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is tied with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines of proper property are placed on it, which is to cut off the blood and tie with a decent compression.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But whoever administers the cutting of it with a ligature and tying with a cloth, or the position of things that burn and similar, does not give it to him completely, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if something happens to him of that, and he is not present with a physician or medicine: then he begins with the position of the finger index over the opening of the vein itself, as we have said, and the compression of it greatly, until the blood is blocked from the upper part of the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger is not removed, above it with cold water of great cold always, until the blood freezes, and thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile he considers in it what is needed from the iron, or from the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	The First Part's End.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part Two.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incisions, Punctures, and Bloodletting in Wounds and Similar Cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already mentioned in Chapter One that all pain which is suitable for the use of a cauterizing fire and burning medicine, along with its causes, reasons, instruments, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed chapters from head to foot there.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I proceed in this chapter the same way: so that it may alleviate those seeking the sought.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary for you to learn, son, what is in this chapter from the fear of that which is in Chapter One about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that reason, it is necessary to have greater caution in it, because in the operation which is in this chapter, often falls evacuation with blood, with which stands life at the opening of the vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of exit, or cure of wound, or extraction of arrow, or incision on stone, and from all these, it is associated with trembling, and fear, and falls in many of them death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you not to fall into that in which is hesitation, for sometimes such people come to you in this art with such ways of men and their weaknesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is he who is angry with his pain, and is light in him towards death: because of the vehemence of it which he found from his weakness and length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with pain is from fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from them is he who gives his song, and enriches you with it, hoping for health, and his pain is destructive.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, it is not necessary to consent to him who comes to you from among them whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And your caution should be more urgent than your greed and your ravenousness.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him unless after a certain certain knowledge which verifies with you that succession is praiseworthy to which he arrives.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use them in the treatment of all your sick, for diagnosis and indication of what is fittingly for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him is to you a helper for the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God breathe into you, O son, his understanding, and not take from you direction and inspiration: for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter of Cauterization, from the scalp to the feet: so that it may be alleviated to you what you seek from him and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ On the treatment of water that gathers in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this infirmity often occurs to children at birth: or when the midwife tightly binds the head of the child without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And also when it happens for an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And indeed I have not seen this ailment in other than children: and to all of whom I have seen from them hasten death: therefore it seemed to me to leave the operation in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And indeed I have seen from them a child whose head was filled with water, and his head was glorified every day, until he could not sit on himself, because of the greatness of his own head: and the moisture increased, until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	This moisture either accumulates between the skin and bone, or beneath the bone above the sinew.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And if the operation is performed on moisture between the skin and bone, and it is a small abscess, then it is necessary to make a cut in the middle of the head, one in width, and the length of the cut should be like two nodes, until the moisture is drained.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the shape of the incision.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then place these two cuts, according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and the sign of it is, that you see the edges of the head open from all parts: and water is pressed when you press it with your hand to the insides, and it does not hide itself from you, then it is necessary to make three cuts in the middle of the head, according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the cuts with cloths and cotton.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then rub it above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then dissolve the ligament, and care for the wound with compresses, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not dismiss binding the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick person with all food dry and little moisture, until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another manner of incision is, that you consider where the size of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For when it is often in the back, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend with the incision where the abscess appears to you and is full of water: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you cut the artery, and blood flow occurs, and the sick person dies from that flow with the discharge of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	On the incision of arteries which are after the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When a person has a catarrh to the eyes, or to the chest, and that is not cured by medical treatment: then the last cure for that person is the incision of those two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore when you wish to incise them, it is necessary that the sick person bend his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person ties his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are locations which are after the ears depressed: and it is rarely hidden, unless in some men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a hot iron on both: and incise both with a narrow knife on each side, the incision going to the bone: and let that be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a narrow knife under the artery, and incise it to the upper part with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is incised, blood escapes with a pulsating flow, which jumps to the inside frequently.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary that you measure from the ear the distance of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with a hot iron, and incise until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which is to be emitted from the blood is six unciae, and perhaps you may emit more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	According to the appearance of the quantity that seems to you due to the weakness of the patient and the filling of his artery, do that.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains at the bone from the siphon anything, then cut that, so that it does not happen that a hot abscess occurs: then bind the wound with lint from a cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ About the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has ancient hemicrania, or sharp catarrh because of acrid humors, and heat in the temples, or old bile, strong, and similar to those: and he is treated with the methods of cure of medicine, and does not bear it: then we have experienced these ailments extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in their extraction is, that the sick one shaves the hairs that are in the temples, and directs himself to the artery that appears in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it is shown to you from his pulse, and rarely is hidden unless in a few men, or because of the vehemence of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is hidden from you, then the sick one binds his head with any of his cloths: then he rubs the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or steam the place with hot water, until it appears to you by a clear appearance.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the little lancet, which I formed a little before.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin with ease, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then thrust in it a hook, and extract it towards the upper parts, until you have extracted it from the skin, and make it go away from the garments that are under it from every part.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is thin: then cover it with the tip of the needle.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the length at which their tips contract and do not cause blood flow.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it does not cut and if it is not cut off, the blood will not rise completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from the blood six ounces, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If however the artery is large: then it is necessary to tie it in two places with a strong double thread of silk or of hair, as not to rush to its putrefaction before the consolidation of the wound and that blood flow does not occur.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut the superfluity which is between the two knots.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cauterizer up to the bone, with a scalpel, until their tips cut and it stands in the place of that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work, unless if he is weak and has a fever or of hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cauterizer is of those that help to end moistures.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the extraction of the arteries, the place should be filled with old cautery: and they should be placed on it well-made pads.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution, it should be treated with dry medicines that make flesh grow and with liniments until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If however in the meantime while you are operating blood flow occurs from the artery, then rush to cut it with a cauterizer or to fill the place with zeolite: and hold your hand, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If nothing of those is present with you, then place it on the place of your finger until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And rub the place with strong cold water until the sharpness subsides and it contracts as it should.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it has a cauterizing knife with this cauterizer having two blades: let the sharpness of the two blades be like alum.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Since if they are as sharp as two knives, each freezes quickly: and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	But since there is a little thickness in them, the heat of the fire is held in them, and the flesh is cut quickly: therefore it is better for every work, and lighter and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let there be a space between the two blades that is as thick as the thickness of your finger, after you have marked two places with the cauterizer: and put both hot ones, until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that it is lengthened between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not harden completely with this cauterizer.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterizer.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ On the care of the course of sharp and frequent tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are frequent and their course is from the eyes which are above the skull externally: and nothing of medicine is applied to them with other medicines, and you see the face of the sick already red, and feels in his forehead a walk, as if it were the walking of ants: and his eyes are weakened, humid, so that already the hair on them has been worn away by corrosion: and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients needed in their cure of these this operation, and called it a cure with the Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is, that you command the sick one to shave the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then, you should make three evenly spaced incisions across the forehead according to its length: and let the length of the incision be about two fingers, and one incision should be evenly spaced with the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length slightly above the shoulder blades, and the third on the other side: and beware of the incision of the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand away from the continuity of the two jaws, and let the entire length of the incision be about three fingers joined together: and let there be a prepared piece of sponge or dry cloth with which to absorb the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then, insert a two-bladed sharp instrument, of which the following is its shape.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is on the temple side, up to the second incision: and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the sphincter, which is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove this instrument and insert another instrument, called a sharp-edged knife, from one side gently, not sharply from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh and skin, and its gentle side towards the bone: and push it until it reaches the middle incision: and cut off with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues up to what appears of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle incision up to another incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	After an equal amount of blood has flowed out, press the areas where the clotted blood is located.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place linen soaked in old cooked linseed in every crack, and place on top of them damp cloths soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And be sure that the abscess does not become hot.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the bandage, and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with basilicon ointment, and with other remedies used to treat wounds: until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ On the care of sharp tears and catarrh from the interior of the head to the eyes.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When sharp catarrh occurs to someone frequently, sharply, and constantly: and you see his eyes weakened, small, and already weakened in appearance: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out from them, and there is a sharp pain in the depth of the head, wounding, and following sneezing: then take from these accidents that those materials, and catarrh do not come, except from many vices.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And a better cure for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you command the sick person to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then cut one incision in the middle of his forehead, or another a little wider in width, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right temple: and let the incision be up to the bone: and keep your hand away from the moving jaws at chewing: until when the bone is exposed: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between two lips of the incision with old cooked linseed, or with linen cloths.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie it above with swabs: and drink swabs with wine and oil, so that no heat abscess may occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you untie it, and see that the heat abscess is already diminishing: then it is necessary to knead the mouth, until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with an evaporating regimen that causes flesh to grow: as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of pitch: and prepare a plaster from them, and administer it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	¶ On the care of that which falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or a stone like it, such as iron and flint: or it is from a plant, such as peas and beans: or it is a fluid, such as water, and vinegar, and the like: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone, or kind of stone from those which do not add and grow in the ear, falls into the ear, expose the Ear alone: if therefore you see the stone, then pour something from broken oil, or sawdust, into the Ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer its extraction, and make him sneeze with the condensed [substance], and open the nose with an onion at the approach of sneezing, after you have placed in the vicinity of the ear fragments of cloth, or wool, and extend the ear to the superior [part].
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Often indeed it goes out with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If however it does not go out, then administer its extraction with Gesti, that is, finely ground pizzarol: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If he goes out with his clothes on, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer the extraction of his tooth with a blunt-ended, fine, thin hook of few doublings.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If he does not come out through that, then make a canula of air, and insert the end of the canula into the ear hole a lot, and put a softened piece of clay with oil around the canula so that there is no wind except for the canula: then extract it with your strong attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Very often he comes out with what we have mentioned.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if he does not come out this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from visco, that is, prepared glue with which birds are caught, a small amount: and put it on the end of the radius after you have wrapped it in a cloth properly placed: then insert it into the ear hole when you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If he does not come out with all that we have mentioned, then hurry to break it before an abscess of hot pus, or spasm, occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of incision is, that you use a lancet on the weak one in the first place in the cephalic: and extract it from his blood according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the weak one sit between your hands, and turn his ear to the superior parts, and make a small incision in the root of the ear at the fatty part of him in the depressed place: and let the incision be in the shape of a crescent moon until you reach the stone: then take it with that which is possible from your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew his incision from your hour with speed, and care for it until he is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If what falling into the ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell: then administer the extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it still does not obey you at the end, then take a thin, delicate spatula in this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the incision of that kind from the grains that fall into your ear, and do not do it when you think that that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you place many pieces of it: then extract them with hooks, or with a thin instrument, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction is relieved.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But in the water that enters your ear, it is necessary to use a weak sneezing with the disinfected first: and now it has filled its own ear with a little old cooked one: and it is lying on that ear, in which there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	Therefore if it comes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of your finger, thin, gentle, and heat them with fire for a while, and the weak one inserts one of them into the hole of its ear: and he salts one of his feet from that part, and strikes with another stone on the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore do not stop doing it with the stone and the stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out so that you take one from the parpyro, or from the junco, and insert one of its ends into your ear: and light the other end with fire, until it is burned a lot of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the junco again, and do it many times, until all the water comes out: and extract it with a cannula as was prescribed in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in the extraction of the animal that enters it, if it is small of body, like a flea, and similar to it, care for it as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	However, if it is a large body part that is visible to the senses: then perform its extraction with forceps and hooks, and its removal is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	However, in the extraction of worms generated in the ear, when you care for it with what we mentioned in division and in the treatment of distillations, and your cure does not combine: then you must look at the ear in the sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	Therefore, if something appears there from the worms, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula, whose form is this: narrow below, wide above: and insert its fine end into the ear according to the amount that an infirm person can bear: then suck with it strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times, until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to exit, then wrap the cannula with ash, as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with that which we said: then perform distillations which the ancients have been experienced in in the piercing of worms: and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be what you pour out oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Just as you see make it from silver, or from brass, below narrow, in which there is a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore let the pushing that is in the hollow of the cannula be made from brass properly.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ray, and wrap it in the end of it with a proper wrapping: then project oil, or succum, or whatever you want from these medicines into the cannula: and it is in the ear: then insert the ray with cotton above, and press it gently by your hand until the oil is pushed into the hollow of the ear, and he feels it inside: and that which is poured into the ear should be already warmed with a little fire: and beware that what is distilled into it is not very cold: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	¶ On the care of the accidental wounding of Gold (possibly a reference to gold fillings or dental work).
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes, certain infants emerge from their mother's wombs unharmed, not having been pierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some men that the wounding of the ear occurs in the opening of the ear due to an injury or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this wounding of the ear sometimes occurs in the deep opening of the ear, which vision does not reach: and sometimes it happens to the outer part of the opening, and vision reaches it.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, that which happens in the deep part of the ear, and which does not include the scope of vision, is often difficult to heal in many positions.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which vision reaches, it is necessary to place the ear of the sick person in the sun, and look at it: then if you see the wounding appearing, open it with a thin, subtle spatula, whose form is as follows: its end is small, and has a slight width; and the rest of the spatula is two-sided, smooth: so that it does not hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the wounding is born from flesh in the opening of the ear: then hold it with a thin tweezer, and cut it with great force until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the wounding is in the deep part of the ear: then take a thin, smooth, warm needle, and heat it with a small fire: then put it into the opening of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you feel the wounding with that which the sick person has, when he has great difficulty hearing, try to open it with ease: and beware, lest you wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear, linen according to the quantity of the foramen's width, which you have soaked in Egyptian ointment. Make it for several days until you are secure about the consolidation of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linen and soak it in rosewater, and sprinkle powdered zeig on it, and use it thus.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see that the ear is already abscessing, then it is necessary to remove the linen and let it with another piece of linen, which you have soaked in rose oil, until the abscess sits warm: then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if bleeding occurs, then immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear: and use the remaining cure, which stops the aforementioned blood flow in the treatment of distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	¶ On the care of Althaea's eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Althaea's which occur in the eyelids of the eye, sometimes are moist, and sometimes are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore you must hold them with tweezers: or with an unguent, and cut them with a lancet from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place powdered zeig on the spots.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lens cauterizer.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterize them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots burn and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	¶ On the care of Granatum's eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It frequently happens that something similar to a storm (Grando) occurs in the eyelids due to its strength and hardness, and because of this it is called Grando. It is an accumulation of thick moisture above the upper eyelid and below the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, the operation in this case is to consider whether it is Grando that is proceeding from what appears from the eyelid and moves to all parts, and its nature is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore, find a cut above it in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from all parts with ease until it becomes smooth.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a probe and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if the cut of it is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with an incision a little, then it harms the weak one in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the cut is large, then gather it with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, you will not encounter harm from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and fleshens it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if Grando is declining towards the inner parts of the ear towards the inner surface, then turn the eyelid and suspend the Grando with a probe: but you will need an incision and press it from all parts.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is lengthened by an incision, it does not harm it in some way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the cut of Grando with salt water: and care for the place with it that fleshens until the weak one heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	¶ On the care of Axirnath of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fatty substance that forms in the eyelids of the upper eyelid: and it particularly affects children: and it makes their eyes heavy, and they get cataracts in the mornings, and they cannot see the light of the sun, because their tears rush to them, and because of this you see them lying on their faces all the time, and they sleep on them, and their eyelids are wet under the swollen eyebrows, which has already been covered by inflation: and the protrusion of Axirnath is visible to the eye, and when you press it with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation for this is that the sick person puts his head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare linseed in it, and make a circle from it of the size that contains Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him on it, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with a sharp lancet making incisions of width, and let there be no incision larger than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary to make an incision in the whole skin, until you reach Axirnath, for in many arrangements Axirnath proceeds from the incision according to the shape of a white fat slice.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then extract it with the cloth that you have placed between your fingers to the outside: and you turn your hand to the right and left, until it is spread: and beware, do not add to the incision, so that it does not reach with the lancet to the eye, and you hurt him.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you will add it with some ease into the incision until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the spot, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some who apply salt to it, and place it in the hollow of the incision, so that what remains from that moisture may melt.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if an abscess occurs in that place, then care for it with soothing plasters, until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	CONCERNING THE WAYS OF ATAXMIR'S EYES, THAT IS, WHEN THE EYEBEAM SOFTENS THE EYES, WHEREBY IT BECOMES SUCH THAT IT TEARS AS IT SHOULD NOT.
Caput XI.	CHAPTER 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	WHEN ADDITIONAL HAIR IS BORN IN THE EYEBEAMS BEYOND ITS NATURAL COURSE UNDER THE HAIR, AND IT AGES: THEN IT HARMS THE EYE, AND CAUSES THE ONSET OF AILMENTS, SUCH AS FREQUENT TEARS, AND SOFTENING OF THE EYEBEAMS, AND WHITE OF THE EYE, UNTIL THAT BECOMES THE CAUSE OF DESTRUCTION OF THE EYE.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	AND ATAXMIR'S EYES ARE CURED ACCORDING TO FOUR WAYS.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	OR BY CAUTERIZATION WITH FIRE.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	OR WITH ACUTE MEDICINE, AS PREVIOUSLY STATED IN THE CHAPTER ON CAUTERIZATION.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	OR ATAXMIR'S EYES ARE CURED BY INCISION AND SUTURING.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	OR BY CANNULAS, AS I WILL SAY.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	IT IS NECESSARY TO PLACE THE HEAD OF THE INFIRM ON YOUR BOSOM.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is turned, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert the needle into it, where the thread is from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread from above, and let it be near the hairs, that is, near the margin of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a forceps.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a probe entering from the larger lacrimal canal up to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread, and place a small amount of cotton or cloth under the eyelid: then mark on the eyelid with a cauterizer, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it must be made like the shape according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: because it is already varied among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who need that a large amount of it should enter from the eyelid according to the quantity which is softened from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with a probe find above two lines which you marked, and begin from the larger lacrimal canal up to the smaller one, and let there be a slit near the natural hairs, like the size of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape it all off.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather it with a suture two lips, with a needle and fine wool thread: and wipe off the blood, and make what is superfluous from the threads over two eyebrows, with some things that cover, if you want to do that: and if not, do not care.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let go of the suture and thread for three days, or four; afterwards care for that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, let go of the wound without suture, and care for it along with that which dries and constricts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised at the sign of the wound and its union: but a better one is to come.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of healing, the ancients taught Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is anxiety over the weak one, and it is from good operation, and there is not in it fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is in Ataxmir also: and it is, that the signs above the eyelid are shaped like a figure, which is like the figure of myrtle leaves, as we have told.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined needles, according to this following form, then cut off what exceeds with small scissors, according to this form, with equality of incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the needle, and it is not equal: then take a needle in which is thread, and insert it in the middle of the figure: and insert another thread near the lacrimal larger, and thread near the lacrimal smaller: and gather the threads with equality between your fingers.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand evenly: and raise the skin over which is marked with the sign, as we have told.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather two lips of the wound with suture: and care for it, until it is healed.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if indeed abscess happens at your incision, or your wound: dry up that abscess with charcoal, and with these similar, from ointments suppressing.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelid also, that its hairs are turned.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we mentioned in the incision in that [place], but a stitch on both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the care of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	AND IT IS, that you turn the eyelid and split the wound which is inside, as I have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	THEN YOU SHOULD MAKE TWO CANES, OR TWO THIN WOODEN STICKS: THE LENGTH OF WHICH SHOULD BE ACCORDING TO THE LENGTH OF THE EYELID, AND THE WIDTH LESS THAN THE WIDTH OF A FINGER: AND YOU ALREADY INCISED IN THE EXTREMITIES OF BOTH FROM BOTH SIDES WHERE YOU HOLD THE THREADS.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	THEN YOU SHOULD AGGREGATE BOTH WITH THINNESS ON TOP OF WHAT OVERFLOWS FROM THE EYELID, AND TIE THE TWO CANES FROM BOTH SIDES WITH A STRONG KNOT, AND LET IT GO FOR SEVERAL DAYS.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	BECAUSE THE SKIN IS TIGHT, IT WILL DIE, DISCOLOR, AND ROT, UNTIL IT FALLS OFF BY ITSELF.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	IF HOWEVER IT DELAYS, THEN CUT IT WITH FORCEPS.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	THEN CARE FOR IT, UNTIL IT HEALS.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	WHEN HOWEVER IT CONSOLIDATES, LIFT THE EYELID: AND DO NOT PICK AT THE HAIR.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	AND THIS IS THE SHAPE OF TWO CANES, WHICH YOU SHOULD MAKE ACCORDING TO THIS FIGURE, AND IN QUANTITY IN LENGTH AND WIDTH.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	ON LIFTING HAIR THAT PRICK THE EYE WITH A NEEDLE.
Caput XII.	CHAPTER 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	THE OPERATION IN THAT IS, THAT YOU TAKE A FINE NEEDLE, AND INSERT IT INTO THE HAIR FROM FINE SILK THREAD, GENTLY.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	THEN YOU AGGREGATE ITS EXTREMITIES, AND TIE BOTH KNOTS WITH A THIN KNOT VERY WELL: AND THE LENGTH OF THE THREAD SHOULD BE ONE FINGER.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then compose in Alinxotati a thin thread under it in short, and knot its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the weak person's head in your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation can be seen: for it is a delicate or minor operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate into the eyelid quickly, until you remove it from above the natural eyelash.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the needle up to above Alinxotati: and insert the needle into Alinxotati if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with it until the needle exits with Alinxotati into the eyelid with the natural eyelash.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however Alinxotati is drawn and the needle does not exit with it: draw Alinxotati to the lower parts, with the thread that you composed in it, until Alinxotati exits from the upper opening, and see it with the vision of the eye: for then draw Alinxotati and the thread, and remove both, and close the eye: and let him be closed for two days or three, until the needle sticks in its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If however the needle is short, then associate with it a long needle from the natural needles, and raise it with it: or let him be, until it lengthens after a time, and then raise it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	¶ On the care of Alinxotati that happens in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alinxotati happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alinxotati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	An accidental wound is caused by the consolidation of a wound, or a cut, or a cauterization, and similar things to these.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operation in it is, that you find that consolidation, and that you separate its lips, and that you put in it what is between them linen from flax, and bind it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you should not use in the treatment of it things that dry and constrict: for if you do that, Alexatrati returns worse than it was: rather use in it those things that soften, such as fenugreek: and rub with water in which althea has been cooked, seed of flax: and unguent dyaquilon, which has been liquefied with some oil: and wrap with it linen, and care for it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasure of treatment is, that you try every ingenuity, that it not consolidate, according to the form that was first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have said, is not but some correction of Alexatrati, that it does not return the form of the place according to what it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	¶ On the care of Alexatrati which is made in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkle or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alexatrati which is below, is what is truly called Alexatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And accidental is caused by a wound, or a cut, or a cauterization, and those similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the method of operation in it is, that you take an acum, in which there is a thread doubled, and you moisten it with flesh, and you make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh towards the upper part with a needle, and cut it with a broad, flat instrument.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the figure of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the ray, and place it in the fissure, and turn it with it the eyelid: and make two fissures in the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two fissures be from two angles of the incision, until they meet and make an angle: until when they gather together, this figure is made, and it is the Greek letter.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount, which is the sharp side of its lower width, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts: sew it with a woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we said about healing ointments and lotions, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alexander's disease occurs from the fissure and the suture, or with a cauterizer: then it is necessary to make the fissure flat under the eyelashes, even as it preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with a lotion, as we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the final word on the care of Alexander when it is above or below, is that the operation should be carried out in it, according to how it is prepared from the form of Alexander.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it is of many diverse forms: and the skilled craftsman prepares his skill with whatever way is possible to him, until he makes the figure return to its natural form, or near to it, and himself the sick person, according to what fits him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Translation: Concerning the adherence of the eyelid to the eye, whether it be united with the conjunctiva or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this adherence occurs to many people in such a way that the upper eyelid becomes united with the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you should insert the tip of the ray under the eyelid and lift it up: or extend it with a spoon: then incise the adherence with a thin, blunt-edged knife, which is not sharp in its incision, but rather dull: so that the weak person does not suffer during the operation, and the knife is removed without damaging the eye with its sharpness: and your incision should be as if you are scraping off the adherence with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form and the adherence is completely healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye with clear water to clean it: or sprinkle it with water from a sponge made of zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen cloth: and place on the eye a woolen cloth soaked in limewater: and use the sponge after three days, and with firm bandages, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Concerning the incision of the nail and the prominence of flesh in the eyes.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You should know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous: and it is similar to a sponge hard and thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to the frozen moisture of a white substance: which when it touches the iron, or you try to take it with a knife, it is cut off and does not stick to the knife.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both species do not begin, except from a larger lacrimal, until it gradually goes, until it covers the sight, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation in its incision is: that he places his weak head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and raise the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the horn with a few notches of the scalpel, and extend it to the upper parts.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle, and insert a pin from horsehair, or goose, or chicken feathers: and let it be a strong thread, and double the tip of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the horn: and pierce it with the needle, and tie the horn with the thread, and extend it to the upper parts: and scrape the side of the horn that follows the pupil, as if you were holding it with the pin until the end of its tail.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.
