Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of some joints from their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore it is prohibited from its motion, and the figure of the member is deformed.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes to happen over the weak pains, and violent injuries.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	Therefore when it happens to someone, then it is necessary to hasten to its restoration: nor does it delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place becomes an abscess, and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it is not necessary, that it be moved, nor stretched in the hour of its abscess.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	Because often it causes to happen spasms, and painful injuries.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when it happens, then it is necessary, that you hasten to the bloodletting of the weak.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it is dismissed, until the abscess rests.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the affected body part should be rubbed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be returned with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And all the body parts should be treated with that which is mentioned in its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	Indeed, I have already arranged the chapters of dislocations according to what preceded in fracture, from the upper part of the body to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	¶ On the care of the dislocation of the lower jawbone.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two lower jaws rarely dislocate.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both occurs according to one of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Either indeed they are moved from their places by a slight movement, and softened for a short time.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated completely, and until they soften to the chest part, until the saliva of the sick person flows out, and he cannot hold it, nor can he close his mouth, and his tongue is wrapped with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	But when the dislocation of it is small, then it returns to many positions by itself with a little bit.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	But if the dislocation is complete and whole: then it is necessary that the reduction of it be administered quickly, and not entirely delayed: and it is necessary for the nurse to hold the head of the sick person: and the physician should insert his one finger of his hand into the root of the lower jaw dislocation between his teeth, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he should insert two fingers of his hand at once, if the dislocation is from both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the other fingers of his hand should be outside, which he balances.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the sick person to clean his jaws, and to make them ready for eating at all parts.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	The doctor balances the mandible and pushes the mandible until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If it is difficult to return it, especially if both mandibles are involved at the same time, then apply heat with hot water and oil until the reduction of both is easy: do not delay the reduction of both at all, as we said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	Therefore, when they return and balance, and the mouth of the sick person is closed and not softened, then place on them cloths of cloth with wax that has been made from wax: and with rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it will be bound with ease with soft ligatures.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient sleep on his back: and his head should be between two cloths, so that he does not move it to the right and left: nor should he try or be forced to chew anything: rather, give him soft food, until when the pains are removed, and the jaw is bound: then he eats what he wants, and is given it with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not labor over the operation of his mouth at eating and drinking, and swallowing, until the jaw is bound, and he is healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If it is difficult to return both mandibles when they are dislocated at some time and do not return to their places, then often fevers and frequent diarrhea occur from this: and perhaps the belly of the sick person is loosened, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	Therefore, when you see this, then you will know that it is a loss, and often that person dies within ten days who experiences this.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the sternum and the extremity of the arm.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The sternum is not dislocated from the inner side, because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated towards the outside: and this is indicated by sensation.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is that the sick person lies on his back, and extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then cut the place with your palm firmly, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place on it a plaster, and bandages, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	In fact, the extremities which follow the arm, and are connected with it, do not usually become dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	But if it becomes dislocated on some day: then it must be reduced and adjusted according to what we said, and that which is prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place on it a plaster, and bandages, and bind it.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the sick person to stick to tranquility and quietness until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when this same cure reduces the extremity of the arm, even if it is separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	¶ On the reduction of the dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You should know that the arm does not become dislocated, except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is, that it becomes dislocated towards the part of the shoulder to the lower parts.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it becomes dislocated towards the part of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it becomes dislocated towards the upper part of the arm: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not become dislocated to the backs, because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not become dislocated to the fronts, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is most often dislocated and removed towards the lower parts towards the shoulder: especially in those whose flesh is little.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because I go out of them quickly, and enter quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those whose flesh is abundant, it is the opposite, that is, he goes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people that they are hit or fall, and the shoulder becomes an abscess with heat, and it is thought to be because of that, since it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, one must try this until you are certain of its truth, and then proceed to its cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is known that the dislocation is when it is towards the inferiors against the acromion: and you distinguish between the dislocated shoulder and the healthy shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find among them a manifest difference, and you will find in the head of the shoulder a hollow, and under the acromion at the touch of the head of the shoulder as if it were an egg: and the weak one cannot reduce his hand to his ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest, or upwards: then you will find a clear touch, and it does not hide.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And this dislocation is easily reduced when it is recent, or the boy is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is that the assistant raises his hand to the upper parts.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then you place your thumbs under his acromion, and raise the joint with strength upwards to its place: and the assistant raises his hand and extends it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he should put it down below, for it returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If not, and if the days since it happened are many: then one must bathe the weak one in hot water, and apply an embrocation that softens and soothes, as if they were boiling the roots of althea, and foenugraecum, and melilot in water, and apply.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the sick person should lie on their back: and place a sphere and wool under their chin, which should be equal in softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the doctor should place their heel on the sphere, and lift up the arm with strength, and pull the hand of the sick person towards the lower parts.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another assistant should hold the head of the sick person, so that they do not move towards the lower parts: for indeed, he returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this manner: and it is, that you make present a man who is longer than the sick person, and stand on the side, and insert his arm under the chin of the sick person: and lift up their chin to the upper parts, until the sick person is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another assistant should pull the hand of the sick person towards the lower parts of their belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the sick person is light: then it is necessary, that he be suspended with something else, which weighs him down: for the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And he is also reduced according to another manner: and it is, that a long piece of wood be shaped on the ground, whose head is round in figure: like the handle of a mortar: which is not thick, nor fine.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then place it under the sick person after they have placed cloth over his head on the piece of wood: and the sick person should stand according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then stretch his hand towards the lower parts on the other side, and stretch his body from the other side with strength: for the joint returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	But if his reduction through all that we have said is difficult: then use this care: and it is, that you take a piece of wood whose length is the quantity of two biceps, and its width is the quantity of four fingers, and its thickness is the quantity of two fingers: which has a round head, so that its entrance into the depth of the chin is eased, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then, clean the round head of the needle, so that it does not wound the weak wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then, place the weak needle under the tilt, so that the hand or arm is stretched over the wood until the lower part: and tie the wood on the support and the arm and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then, place the arm on the width of the ladder step, and stretch the hand to the lower part, and let go of the remaining body hanging from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	Therefore, when the entrance to it is completed according to any possible mode: then it is necessary to place under the tilt an equal quantity of woolen ball from the lamb.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then, place the prepared plaster from the flour mill with bdellium and egg white on the entire arm, as it rolls over.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then, tie under the tilt a decent binding: and roll the bandage over the plaster above: and attach his hand to his neck, and let go, and do not move his hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary to place food for the weak one, until the member is strengthened: because it is faster for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then, place a larger one after seven days or five, and exercise it with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If therefore it is strengthened and not softened, then it is already healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	But if the joint is often dislocated due to moisture that happens to it, or for another reason: then it is necessary to administer a cautery in it with three holes, according to what was prescribed in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	But if this is all done, and the bandage is dissolved after seven days, and the joint is not strengthened, and the plaster and binding are rolled back over it several times, and it does not strengthen, and it falls, and it cannot be raised to the upper parts: then you know that the nerves of his arm which are near the head of the humerus, have been cut, or stretched, or softened: and you know that the joint will never be in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	For dislocations that occur towards the chest and breasts, or towards the back, reduction is achieved with impulse and extension of the hands: until it returns to its original position, and it is treated with the remaining bandaging and care, until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If, after healing, there is a severe injury in the limb and slowness in its movement, then the patient should frequently use the bathhouse, until that severity is eased, and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	§ On the Treatment of Dislocation of the Elbow.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You should know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty, and it also returns to its original position with difficulty: and indeed it can be dislocated in all directions, and especially towards the front or the back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it falls under the sight and touch, in whatever shape it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated elbow to a healthy one, it is clearly shown to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For indeed the joint is bent, and it cannot double the arm, nor touch its own shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary for you to act quickly and reduce the dislocation immediately, before an inflammation of hot pus occurs in it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if an inflammation of hot pus occurs in it, its reduction becomes difficult: and perhaps it will not be healed at all, especially when it is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For indeed it is worse in all kinds of dislocations, and more intense pain arises from them: and it often dies along with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration when it is from those that can be reduced, is to extend the hand with both hands: and the arm is expanded, and the hands of the physician are above the elbow and below it, and he pushes the joint with his fingers or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its original place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or rather, it is a dislocation towards the front: then he should return as follows, so that he doubles his hand with his own hand, until he strikes with the root of his palm his own elbow which is dislocated.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	But if the dislocation does not obey reduction, then administer strong, very forceful extension: and it is, so that two assistants extend the arm, and two assistants also hold him, so that he is not moved during extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm should be rolled back to all parts after it has been unrolled over his hand, with a long doubled cloth or broad ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches the joint with his hand, he should anoint it with oil: so that it is from those which help in the lubricity of the joint with facility.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he should push the joint with strong impulse, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction, it is necessary that it be placed on it a plaster, in which there is stipticity, and exiccation with whiting: and it is bound with a proper bandage.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm should be suspended from the neck of the weak: and let it be released for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it should be unbound.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	But if the joint is strengthened in its place, then unbind the ligament from it, and let it be released.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not well bound, then repeat the plaster, and the ligament, and let it be released for several days, until it is bound.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then unbind it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	But if a seriousness occurs to him after the reduction of the joint, and the position is in motion: then administer moisture in bathing, and gentle friction, and compression, until it is lined, or place on the joint, that is, the fat of a young ram.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then bind it up and let her go on that day and at night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove it and put him into a bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When he sweats, then gently rub the joint with moderate friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat the application of the ointment once, and twice, and three times with entry into the bath, until it is soothed.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place on her the warm dung of a cow, moistened with hot butter, and wrap it around him.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For she is indeed soothed, and returns to her proper condition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	¶ On the treatment of dislocation of Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	Almahassem's hand is often dislocated, that is, the joint that is between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And its reduction of dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	On the contrary, the rest of the joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it is necessary that the speed of the reduction of this dislocation be in the hour in which it occurs, before the wound closes: or an hot abscess occur in it.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of the dislocation is such that one places Almahassem's weak hand on a table, and extends the minister's hand: and the physician places his hand on the prominence of the joint, and pushes it, until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, it is necessary to consider if the palm of the hand has already receded to the wrist: then one places the weak back of his hand on the table at extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding to the back of the hand, then the position of his hand is inside on the table, that is, the inner part of his hand is placed on the table, so that the hand of the physician falls on that prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If he returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then bind it with a plaster containing a styptic for the stoppage of the abscess, and do not repeat this.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if he does not tolerate it, and you are unable to apply further reduction to him, after the days pass by, nevertheless the union remains according to its curvature: and nothing harms the sick except that the hand becomes soft, and cannot bind anything: then you know that the nerves have been cut or torn.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is therefore no other skill in it than to bind it with a cauterizing iron near the wound.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it does not heal anything.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When therefore Albucasis does not return, then apply the plaster which we have mentioned to him.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then he is bound and let go for five days: after that, it is dissolved and let go, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if his movement is lost, and something heavy occurs to him: then ease it with warm water, and friction several times, until it is eased.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	¶ On the Cure of Dislocations of the Fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When the finger is dislocated from any of them, or the finger from the back of the palm, or its belly: then extend the finger, and push the dislocation with your fingers, until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, and suspend it turned towards the part to which it is dislocated, and let it go for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it, until it becomes straight on its day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore it is night, bind it according to the same account: and do not cease to dissolve it in the day: and exercise it with movement: and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for several days until it is tightly bound.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same with it if it is dislocated towards the palm of your hand: and bind it to that part, and perform your first operation on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And do the same with it when it is dislocated towards the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ On the treatment of dislocation of the sacrum in the back.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to someone that the sacrum in the back or the neck is completely dislocated, or many spines are moved from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death approaches the weak person.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the sickness of the weak person passes out without will, and he cannot hold it: and often some of his limbs are softened from it, or both his legs, or both his arms, or one of them: or one spine is moved from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For often it is moved, because often the movement of them happens to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Those therefore which are moved towards the back, are called Gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The cure of this however is, that you consider at that time, if Gibbosity happens from childhood: then there is no cure for it, nor is there any healing at all from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	In that however which happens by chance, or by blow, or by similar things, the ancients have already spoken of a lengthy method of cure in their talk.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which very little returns with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I however have already abbreviated from it, of which little excuses it from much of its proximity to my intention: and from my exposure which I exposed it, and formed an instrument of it in a different way than they showed it, and exposed it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore, that in the hardness which occurs from the front part, there is no skill, nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly in that which is made on both sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not treated from them, except that which occurs on the back properly, when I say: and it is, that the weak one be stretched out on his face on a board near the wall: and the wet cloth is spread under him, so that he is not harmed by his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight piece of wood is placed on the floor, in the end of the board, near his head: and another piece of wood near his feet in the other end of the board: and the servant holds the wood, and it is not firmly fixed in the fork.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And the other servant holds the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then he is rolled over on the weak one's head, and under his tongue a strong bandage, firm: and extend the end of the bandage to the wood that is by his head: and tie it in it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then tie another bandage above his heels, and above his knees, and by his calves.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the bandages, and tie them on the other wood that is by his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all the servants stretch out to the part of the wood where the bandage is tied, and the two woods are not moved from the places where they are fixed: but they are not tightened, as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the doctor puts his hands on the spine with strength, until he returns: or puts a board on it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he connects his feet on the board, until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if he does not return by this cure, then take a board whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And also prepare a location on the wall that we mentioned is near the weak one, where the end of the board can enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board on the Spondyle.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the doctor put his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And he should tie it well until the Spondyle is covered, and then return to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with the saw that is wrapped around your hand: and it is to make two pieces of wood on the ground near the head of the sick person in the last of the feet, whose length is the arm of one: and at his head in the last of the feet, two pieces of wood.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And its length should be the same as every wood, a palm: and now there is a hole in every place where the saw ran: and all the wood is firmly fixed on the ground, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And the round wood is inserted: and there is a saw in which the ligament is rolled up in two holes of two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end is a hole, in which the wood that is firmly fixed, whose length is the same as that which rolls up, is in two other pieces of wood.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tie the ligaments that you tied in the chest of the sick person with the saw that is at his head: and the ligaments that you tied in his legs with the saw that is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand by every saw, which turns the hand with the leather, with which the saw is rolled up: and the doctor balances the Spondyle, as we said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the shape of the saw that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then when the Spondyle returns and the place is balanced, then you should put an evaporative plaster with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then, a bandage.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Afterwards, place a stellate bandage above the plaster, whose width is three fingers, or about that.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length is the amount that will cover the sacrum and on the healthy spine.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is tied with the bandage we mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the sick person should use this delicate nourishment until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If something remains prominent in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and alleviate, with the administration of the tablet we mentioned for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now it is applied to that lead sheet.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes a prominence occurs at the last spine of the back: and it is thought to be due to dislocation, and that is the bone that already protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not necessary to make a presumption about him with this medicine: for perhaps he will cause death to happen.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Chapter on the treatment of a dislocated ankle.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that the joint of the ankle and the joint of the arm do not occur except in dislocation alone: nor does it happen to them that what happens to the other joints from slight removal and concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the joint of the ankle is dislocated according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is dislocated towards the front and the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And it is very much dislocated towards the inside: and a little dislocated towards the front and the back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment of the dislocation towards the inside is because when you join the leg of the sick person with the sick, it is longer: and his knee is higher than that of the healthy one, and the sick person cannot double his foot near the groin: and the place that follows the groin is swollen with hot abscess, therefore because the head of the hip has already reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And its sign, which occurs when there is a dislocation to the exterior, is that it is opposite in nature to these accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And its sign, which occurs when there is a dislocation to the front, is that it stretches the healthy leg according to its complement: however, it does not double it without pain in the knee: and if it tries to walk, it cannot step forward: and it retains its urine, and it develops an abscess in its groin, and it limps when walking, stepping on its heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And its sign, which occurs when there is a dislocation to the back, is that it does not stretch the knee, and it cannot double it before doubling the groin: and its leg is also shorter than the other: and the groin is softened, and it is the hip joint at the place of the other.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this type of dislocation is indeed, that you should consider whether the dislocation is old and has already outlived its time in the one who has it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer its reduction, and it remains according to its position, then there is no cure at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, it is not necessary to make a complete assumption of it.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in the one whose dislocation is recent, and it is of a type of four dislocations: then hasten to this, that you fold the joint, and extend it both to the interior and to the exterior, and move it with your right and left hand: for perhaps it returns, and does not require any other cure.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if it does not return in this way, then you must prepare a strong assistant, and extend the leg from the lower part: or with your hands, or with a bandage that is tied above the leg on the knee: and another assistant extends his hand above, so that he may insert his hands under the tendons of it.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he ties with a thin ligature over the root of the thigh bone, and holds the end of the other ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And it should be extended from the front part of the groin to the part of the backbone, or from the back to the part of the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And it should be extended with one pull of equal strength, until the weak one is lifted up with his body from the ground, and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	For this kind of extension is a common kind among the four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation returns with what we said, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary for every kind of that which I will say about its proper cure.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In the proper reduction of it, however, when the dislocation is to the insides, it is necessary that the weak one should lie down on his sound side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then let him place the ligament over the root of the thigh bone, in that which is between the hip joint and the part under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then let him extend the ligament upwards from the part of the groin to the higher part of the body, to the part of the backbone.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then let another strong assistant take his arms, and reduce the large part of the weak one's hip, and extend it to the outer extension with great force.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	Now indeed it returns to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier of all kinds of cures by which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if it excuses itself to you, and does not obey you with this kind of cure at all: then it is necessary that two weak feet should be bound together with a strong ligament, and a thin one, over the two heels, and over the two knees; and the length of each should be equal to four fingers from its corresponding part: and the weak leg should be extended more than the other by the length of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the sick person is suspended over the head of a tree, which is in the house, and its length should be equal to the distance from the ground to the armpit of two men.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong young man to protect the hip: and suspend him with the sick person in another place: and push the other young man, protecting the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	However, in its proper reduction, when it is a dislocation to the outside, it is necessary for the sick person to lie on the stool, as we mentioned in one with gibbosity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And the tendon is tied over his leg, the sick person properly, and on his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two beams are placed, one at his feet, and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then the additional beam is placed in the middle of the foot, firmly fixed: on which wet cloths are laid, so that it does not hurt the sick person: and the beam should be between his hips, so that it is not pulled downwards during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the servants stretch to their part, and the doctor equalizes the reduction by his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore it obeys the return, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place a board on it, and press it evenly, as we said in gibbosity.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary for the sick person to lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary for the sick person's leg to be stretched quickly: and it is according to this same narrative on the stool: and the doctor places his right hand palm on the sick person's hip.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he binds him with his other hand, and with that binding place him stretched towards the lower part to the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is to the rear: then it is not necessary for the injured person to be extended downwards and raised up on the ground: rather, it is necessary for them to be placed on a hard surface, just as it is necessary for them to be placed in such a position if their ankle is dislocated outwards, according to what we said about their reclining position on two ankles: and the ligaments are stretched, as we said recently.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary to apply compression with a board even on the place from which the joint exits, when the reduction is completed according to what is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its reduction is not hidden from you: and it is that you extend both the injured legs: and when you see them equal, and the injured person contracts their leg and expands it without any excuse: then you know that the limb has already returned, according to what is necessary: then join the two thighs and apply a plaster, and bind with imemati, that is, a wheel: in such a way that the ankle does not move towards any part of the body: and let the injured person remain quiet for three days or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament, and the plaster, and compare the leg with the other: then if you see them equal in position, then you know that the dislocation is already firm: therefore complete the injured person for walking.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see anything of softening: then return and apply the plasters again, and bind it according to your first binding: and let it go for three days also.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then loosen it and make it slow in walking on both sides for several days until it is strong again.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	On Dislocation of the Knee
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	The dislocation is directed towards the externals, internals, and inferiors, namely towards the posteriors.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated towards the anteriors.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you command the sick person to apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	But if it does not stick to the hip, then you will know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all its modes of dislocation is to make the sick person sit straight, so that he can extend his leg as much as possible over it, and his back against his face: and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then hold the knee with your hands, and straighten them across your fingers above the knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your hand two sides of the knee with force.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another servant extends his foot until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of its return is that the leg sticks to the hip in ease, not with difficulty.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply plasters to him, and make the leg stick to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it together with a bandage and a splint for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then unbind it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And the sick person should not use walking for several days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if he refuses to reduce it to you, then apply strong extension with bandages, of which the previous description is given in the cure of the ankle, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	On the cure of the dislocation of the heel bone.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel bone sometimes moves slightly and sometimes is dislocated according to the complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation is made, either towards the internals, or towards the externals.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	The sign of its dislocation is that you see the calcaneum (heel bone) inflated, protruding towards the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	However, its cure and removal are easy to restore: and it is to be stretched gently with the hands, and evened, until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In its cure however, when it dislocates according to the complement, it is necessary that you make the patient sit upright: and hold it firmly with a strong helper from the posterior part of his back, in the middle of itself.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold you with your right hand from the upper part of his foot, and with your left hand from the lower part of his foot in the place of the heel.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left hand in two ways.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then stretch with your left hand, and push the foot's chest towards the leg without labor.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice, as we have said.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the foot's chest towards the leg in the third way, and you pull the heel.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore it returns to the first way, or to two ways according to this method, and you see the foot evened, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation on it: for it returns.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if it is prohibited to you to reduce it with that which we have said: then make the patient lie down on his back on the ground, and fix a firm board in the ground strongly, so that he falls between his hips: and you have already uncovered over him the cloth, so that he does not hurt the patient.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the helper receive his hip: afterwards let the helper extend his foot, or with his hands, or with a band that ties on the neck of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then every assistant should stand against the extension of his equal: and a staff should be standing between the two hips of the sick person, holding him so that he is not drawn by his body towards the lower parts during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician equalizes the dislocation with his hands, and the other assistant holds the healthy leg towards the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For dislocation returns quickly.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	Therefore when the dislocation returns and you are told of its health of return: then place a plaster and bandage, and bind it firmly with bands, and tie the foot with a band to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you beware of the cavities or fear the nerves which are above the heel of the back, so that there is not a strong band over them and they are not harmed.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let him go for two days or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the band is softened, bind it again: then dissolve it on the third day or fourth day: and prevent the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	Indeed if he tries to walk before that time, there is no safety that the dislocation above him does not dissolve and decay, and does not receive after that cure.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If however a boil hot occurs to him: then it is necessary that the attendant in the sedation of him in which our previous account preceded in another place from the cure and ointment, until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	§ On Dislocation of Toes of the Foot, and Cure.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that what is dislocated be equalized with them by extension a few without labor: and indeed this is not difficult, but easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If however the dislocation is in certain bends of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that he make the sick person sit his foot on a level with the earth, or on a board: and standing like walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you should stand and place your foot upon that which is higher than the others among those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then step on it with your foot with strength until it returns, and see that it is now evened out, and does not appear to be raised in place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place a board under its belly which can take the whole foot, with two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then bind it with a decent binding for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then dissolve it and let it rest from walking for many days, until it is bound and secured from the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	¶ On the kinds of dislocation with a wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens to it and you try to cure it and restore it, death often follows: and because of this, it is not fitting for anyone to presume on its cure, which is such as this, unless he is wise in the art with long practice, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous; and that he use in the beginning of medical treatments which only stop boils with hot: and let him send away the sick by divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see or hope for health from the destruction with the alleviation of illness, and in which something appears to be of hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Then try its reduction immediately at the beginning of the matter, before boil hot occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the member returns, as we wish, then administer the regimen which stops boil: and care for the wound with that which is appropriate to it from drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If then the dislocation is with fracture, and they occur in the bones of the separated shoulder, then try to remove them, and make in it what we said in simple illnesses from that which preceded in those places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And keep your wound clean according to your ability, and guard yourself from the entrance into the path of fear: as my previous warning advised you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you before your Creator, and more enduring to your glory, and more saving for your body among them in your time.
